misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (implemented acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of summing even numbers from 5 integers as specified in the question.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe the task is to write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of those integers are even using a condition like `n % 2 == 0`, and print the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Program reads three double values instead of five integers.
Program computes `(V1 - V0) / T` and prints an acceleration message instead of summing even numbers.
No loop, no modulus operator `%`, and no even-number check are present.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this question with a different textbook-style problem about computing average acceleration, suggesting they did not carefully align their solution with the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and underline each requirement: number of inputs (5), type of inputs (integers), condition (only even numbers), and required output (sum of those even numbers). Before coding, write a short plan in comments that directly references these requirements, then implement that plan.
related_concepts: Test case design to check against the sample run
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because every part of the program (prompt, variable names, formula, and output message) corresponds to an acceleration problem and none of the required elements for summing even numbers is present.

evidence.note: The prompt, variable names, input pattern, and formula clearly implement an average acceleration calculation, not reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect problem implementation
misconceptions.description: The student's submission calculates average acceleration (A = (V1 - V0) / T) and does not implement any of the required logic for finding the sum of even numbers (reading 5 integers, looping, conditional checks for evenness, accumulation). The code addresses a completely different assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the code for a different program (calculating acceleration) and believes it satisfies the requirements for the 'Sum of Even Numbers' assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading five integer inputs, iterating through them, using a conditional expression (modulus operator) to check for even numbers, and accumulating only the even numbers into a final sum variable.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integers.
Calculates a physical quantity (acceleration) instead of a cumulative sum.
Absence of any loop structure or conditional logic related to even number checking.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to address the core problem requirements; likely submitted the solution to the wrong assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the instructions for Q1 ('Sum of Even Numbers'). You need to use a loop to handle 5 inputs, and use the modulo operator (`%`) inside a conditional statement (`if`) to identify and sum the even integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code structure, variable names (V0, V1, T, A), and output message confirm calculation of average acceleration, which is totally unrelated to the required task.

evidence.note: This code implements the acceleration formula, demonstrating a complete misunderstanding or mis-submission of the required task.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have misunderstood the assignment entirely. The assignment asks for a program that reads 5 integers and sums the even numbers, but the student wrote a program that calculates acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t with 3 inputs instead.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a different problem—calculating average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user, filtering for even numbers (using n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum. The sample input/output clearly shows: 'Enter 5 integers: 3 8 2 7 4' should result in 'Sum of even numbers: 14' (8 + 2 + 4 = 14).
symptoms: Program prompts for 3 velocity/time values instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of summing even numbers
Output is completely different from expected output
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have solved an entirely different problem, possibly copying code from a physics-related exercise or misreading the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. The task requires: (1) reading 5 integers, (2) looping through them, (3) checking if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) accumulating the sum of only even numbers, and (5) printing the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) rather than the stated assignment (sum of even numbers). There is no ambiguity here—the student submitted code for the wrong problem entirely.

evidence.note: The code prompts for v0, v1, and t (three velocity/time values) and calculates acceleration, which is completely different from the assignment requirement to read 5 integers and sum even numbers.
Class name 'Acceleration' suggests the student was working on a physics problem, not the assigned even-number-sum problem.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of a program that reads 5 integers and sums only the even ones. This indicates a misunderstanding of what the assignment is asking for, rather than a minor implementation mistake.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop and a conditional to identify which of those integers are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
Program reads 3 double values, not 5 integers.
No loop is used to process 5 inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0).
Program computes an acceleration formula ( (V1 - V0) / T ) instead of a sum of even integers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem statement or reuse of code from a different assignment (average acceleration) instead of implementing the specified task (sum of even numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the question carefully and restate it in your own words. Identify the required inputs (5 integers), the processing steps (loop over 5 values, check evenness with n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum), and the required output (sum of even numbers). Then design your code structure around these requirements before you start typing.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program solves a different textbook problem (average acceleration) and does not include any elements of the requested task (reading 5 integers, checking for even numbers, summing them).

evidence.note: This code clearly implements the average acceleration formula using three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones as required.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements (Input Count)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a different arithmetic problem (calculating average acceleration) that reads exactly 3 inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading the required 5 integers for the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment was about calculating average acceleration, or they submitted code from a different assignment entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 explicit integer inputs and processing them according to the 'Sum of Even Numbers' requirement. The acceleration formula is completely irrelevant to the problem statement.
symptoms: Incorrect program output/functionality compared to problem statement
Prompts for different variables (v0, v1, t)
Reads 3 inputs instead of 5
Uses double data type for input when integer was specified
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to address the core problem requirements (reading 5 integers and summing evens). It is highly likely the student pasted code from a previous exercise or misunderstood which question they were answering.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Completely review the problem statement for Q1: 'Sum of Even Numbers'. Your current code calculates acceleration, which is a different task entirely. You need to implement the logic for reading 5 numbers using a loop and checking for parity (even/odd).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code addresses an entirely different problem (Acceleration calculation) than the prompt (Sum of Even Numbers). This is a definitive failure to meet any requirement of the assigned task.

evidence.note: The code reads inputs for calculating acceleration (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 general integers for summation.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type for Input (Double vs. Integer)
misconceptions.description: The assignment specifies reading 5 *integers*, which implies an integer data type (e.g., `int` in Java). The student's submission uses `double` for all inputs (`V0`, `V1`, `T`). While functional for the code they wrote (acceleration), it does not adhere to the requirements of the actual assignment which involves parity checks typically done with integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `double` is the appropriate general-purpose numeric type, even when the prompt specifically asks for integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Integers should be stored using the `int` data type unless a calculation specifically requires floating-point precision, or if the input size exceeds the `int` range. For 'Sum of Even Numbers', `int` is appropriate and necessary for the modulus operator (%) to function as intended for whole number parity checks.
symptoms: Use of `nextDouble()` method
Declaration of variables as `double`
misconceptions.root_cause: The student used the wrong formula, which also dictated the wrong data type (doubles are standard for physics calculations). This error is secondary to the primary misconception, but still shows a misunderstanding of data type relevance when reading input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure you are using the correct data type (e.g., `int`) when the problem specifies integers, especially for tasks involving even/odd checks which rely on the properties of whole numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as 'Sum of Even Numbers' requires whole numbers, but the implementation uses floating-point types.

evidence.note: Using nextDouble() and storing values in doubles when the problem requires reading integers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution to a completely different problem (calculating acceleration from v0, v1, and time) instead of the assigned problem (summing even numbers from 5 integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate average acceleration using the formula A = (V1 - V0) / T.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which ones are even (divisible by 2), and output their sum.
symptoms: Code solves a physics problem instead of the assigned sum-of-evens problem
Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
No loop structure despite multiple inputs required
No even-number checking logic present
Output is acceleration calculation, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have solved a different assignment or failed to read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully. Create a program that: (1) reads 5 integers in a loop, (2) checks if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulates the sum, and (4) prints the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submission is unmistakably solving a different problem. The variable names (v0, v1, t, A), the formula, and the output all indicate a physics acceleration problem rather than the assigned even-number-sum problem.

evidence.note: The entire program solves for acceleration (A = (V1-V0)/T) with 3 inputs (v0, v1, t), completely unrelated to the assigned problem of summing 5 even integers.
Class name 'Acceleration' indicates the student is solving a physics problem, not the assigned sum-of-evens problem.
